summary: tobacco mosaic virus (TMV), the type member of tobamovirus genus, is a prevalent plant pathogen all over the world. it has the widest host range of over 885 plant species in 65 families. in certain fields 90–100% of the plants show mosic or leaf necrosis by harvesting time. this plant virus has the name “plant cancer” and is difficult to control. chemical structures of compounds 1–24, Ribavirin, Ningnanmycin, Cryptopleuridine and (R)-Antofine offer advantages in that they can sometimes be specific to a target species. another benefit is their ability to decompose rapidly, thereby reducing their risk to the environment. phenanthroquinolizidine and phenanthroindolizidine alkaloids 1–24 were prepared and systematically evaluated for their antiviral activity against TMV. phenanthroquinolizidine alkaloids 10–17 were synthesized by using a synthetic approach involving coupling of the phenanthrene ring with 2-bromopyridine through a nucleophilic substitution reaction and subsequent reduction of the resulting pyridyl ketone as key steps. the hydrogenation of 26f was carried out at several different conditions. treatment of compound 26f with PtO2 in the solution of acetic acid and trifluoroacetic acid (v/v 41) at 50 atm gave the carbonyl group reduced intermediate 29 in 53% yield. phenanthroquinuolizidine alkaloids 16 and 17 were designed and synthesized. tic acid and trifluoroacetic acid (v/v 51) at 10 atm gave 38 in 82% yield. treatment of ketone 35 with Pd/C as the catalyst in reluxing acetic acid at 1 atm gave the key intermediate 38 in 59% yield. treatment of pyridine 37 with cyclopropylmethyl bromide obtained 41, which deprotected phenanthroquinuolizidine alkaloid 16 in 69% yield. olizidine alkaloids showed higher antiviral activity than Ribavirin. cryptopleurine (1) and alkaloid 16 showed significantly higher antiviral activity than (R)-antofine. cryptopleurine (1) and alkaloid 16 exhibited significantly higher antiviral activity than (R)-antofine. cryptopleurine (1) and alkaloid 16 exhibited significantly higher antiviral activity. the removal of methoxyl at 7-position of the phenanthrene moiety is beneficial for mataining excellent antiviral activity. alkaloid 7 showed significantly higher activity than alkaloid 7. removal of 6-O methyl increased the antiviral activity. cyclopropyl methyl significantly decreased the antiviral activity. replacement of 2,3-dimethoxyl or 6,7-dimethoxyl with methylenedioxyl is tolerant. but replacement of 2,3-dimethoxyl or 6,7-dimethoxyl with ethylenedioxyl significantly increased the anti-TMV activity. in vitro and in vivo anti-TMV activity of chiral phenanthroquinolizidine alkaloids 2, 3, 5, 6, 8 and 9. HCl (2 mL) was added. the reaction mixture was refluxed for 24 h in the dark, then evaporated under reduced pressure to remove most of the ethanol. the solid was dissolved in CH2Cl2 and washed with aqueous NaOH. the mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated to dryness in vacuo. the combined organic extracts were dried over anhydrous NaOH. the residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel. the solid was collected and dried, then dissolved in methanol (600 mL) the mixture was refluxed for 20 h with the exclusion of moisture, then concentrated in vacuo. the residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel. the mixture was cooled to room temperature and extracted with CH2Cl2 (3200 mL) the combined organic layer was washed with brine (200 mL) and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered and concentrated in vacuo. residue was purified by flash column chromatography on silica gel with EtOAc/petroleum ether. the residue was recrystallized from CH2Cl2 and petroleum ether to give alcohol 36 (1.2 g, 83%) as a white powder. a mixture of 36 (1 mmol), trifluoroacetic acid (60 mL) and triethylsilane (10 mL) was refluxed for 8 h. a mixture of 38 (1 mmol), (Boc)2O (9.3 mmol) and saturated NaHCO3 solution (1.5 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 3 h, then extracted with CH2Cl2 (350 mL) the combined organic layer was washed with brine (250 mL), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered and concentrated in vacuo. a mixture of compound 40 (0.08 mmol) and 10% Pd/C (0.1 g) in THF (50 mL) was stirred for 36 h under hydrogen in the dark. the mixture was stirred for 10 h at room temperature, then quenched with H2O (100 mL), then extracted with CH2Cl2 (350 mL). a mixture of 41 (1 mmol), conc. HCl solution (5 mL), ethanol (100 mL) and PtO2H2O (0.1 g) was stirred for 36 h at a pressure of 50 atm under hydrogen. the mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated to dryness in vacuo. (4200 mL) and brine (2200 mL), dried over anhydrous Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated in vacuo. solution obtained was cooled, extracted with ether (3100 mL) and carefully acidified with concentrated (0.87 g, 82%) by using a similar procedure for the synthesis of compound 30 except for under hydrogen at a pressure of 10 atm. mixture of methanone 35 (4 mmol) and 10% Pd/C (0.16 g) in acetic acid was HCl solution (5 mL), ethanol (100 mL) and PtO2H2O (0.1 g) was stirred for 36 h at a pressure of 50 atm under hydrogen. the mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was evaporated to dryness in vacuo. the halves were immersed into the solution of 500 g/mL of compounds and double distilled water for 20 min. each compound was replicated at least three times. the local lesion numbers appearing 3–4 days after inoculation were counted. the local lesion numbers appearing 3–4 days after inoculation were counted. the in vitro and in vivo inhibition rates of the compound were then calculated according to the following formula. inactivation effect of compounds against TMV in vivo The virus was inhibited by mixing with the compound solution at the same volume for 30 min. the mixture was then inoculated on the left side of the leaves of tobacco (Nicotiana tabacum var Xanthi nc) the local lesion numbers were recorded 3–4 days after inoculation. compounds 1, 2, 15 and 16 displayed significantly higher activity than (R)-antofine and commercial Ningnanmycin at the same test condition. introduction of 6-hydroxyl, which is proposed to interact with TMV RNA, did increased anti-TMV activity. the 14aR-configuration was confirmed to be preferred antiviral configuration for phenanthroquinolizidine alkaloids.
